definition: to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
to mix/to mingle/muddled/to drift along/to muddle along/to pass for/to get along with sb/thoughtless/reckless
variant of 視|视[shi4]/variant of 示[shi4]
to listen/to hear/to obey/a can (loanword from English "tin")/classifier for canned beverages
(literary pronunciation, still advocated in Taiwan) to rule/to sentence/to allow

sentences.english: A restaurant trade group slammed the study, calling it misleading.
sentences.chinese: 某家快餐店猛烈的抨击了该研究，称他是混淆视听。

sentences.english: Well, that's what they do when they get jealous, they confuse it.
sentences.chinese: 呵呵，那就是他们嫉妒的时候做的事，混淆视听。

sentences.english: The first is to confuse ends and means.
sentences.chinese: 首先是混淆视听的目的和手段。

sentences.english: This is absolutely in promiscuous seeing and hearing, it is false news.
sentences.chinese: 这绝对是在混淆视听，是假新闻。

sentences.english: Why is always misunderstood, Luoyang, Xi'an, can easily confuse it?
sentences.chinese: 为什么洛阳总是被人误解，西安能够轻易混淆视听呢？

definition: to discredit/to defame/to smear sb's name/to bring shame upon (oneself or one's family etc)/to blacken (e.g. commando's face for camouflage)/to black out or obliterate (e.g. censored words)
lit. to invert black and white (idiom); to distort the truth deliberately/to misrepresent the facts/to invert right and wrong
lit. to graft flowers onto a tree/to surreptitiously substitute one thing for another (idiom)
to start rumours and create trouble
lit. to put Zhang's hat on Li's head/to attribute sth to the wrong person (idiom)/to confuse one thing with another
sensationalism/vulgar claptrap to please the crowds/playing to the gallery/demagogy
to compile/to draw up/to fabricate/to invent/to concoct/to make up/to cook up
